awd_titl_txt: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: Computing with Biomolecules: From Network Motifs to Complex and Adaptive Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Can molecules be organized, or even self-organize, to perform complex tasks? This question seemingly should have an answer in the affirmative, because all the world around us, and especially the living things in it, is a mass of molecules. Yet the complexity of molecular systems, or networks, that chemistry has achieved to date pales in comparison with electronics and computers. A team of chemists, engineers, and computer scientists join forces to explore how molecules can be harnessed to achieve complex behaviors, including simple forms of computation, adaptation, and learning. They will work to discover the engineering principles needed to make large and useful molecular circuits. They will start by building networks of DNA enzymes, where actions of one enzyme stimulate another, just as protein enzymes stimulate one another in a living cell. They will build networks that can detect patterns of change in the environment; for example, the strength and the frequency of a periodic stimulation. Ultimately, they will build large networks that embody the ability to learn (memorize and generalize) patterns of past stimulation, and respond to new conditions in the environment accordingly.

Intellectual Merit: The project will develop biocompatible, DNA molecular sensors and actuators that will be of immediate use in pathogen detection, non-invasive diagnostics, and intelligent therapeutics. As the project progresses, these will be combined with ever more capable biomolecular learning machines we will develop, but they can also be used independently by other researchers or medical doctors.

Broader Impacts: The project will reach out to underserved communities in Oregon, New Mexico, and inner-city New York, providing high-school students and undergraduates an opportunity to engage in interdisciplinary scientific research.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to advance synthetic biochemical circuitry capable of
learning and adaptation, and was one of the projects funded under the
Cyber-enabled Discovery and Innovation program (CDI).  The project applied
computer science principles of modeling and architectural design to identify and
develop novel DNA biochemistry that embodied aspects of learning and
adaptation. The question that guided the project was: Given that all life
exhibits adaptation, and most life exhibits some form of learning, what might be
the simplest repertoire of synthetic biochemistry that can mimic these
behaviors?

Among the principal research outcomes:

1. We developed a series of candidate architectures for the classification task
of machine learning based on artificial chemistries and reducible to DNA strand
displacement reactions.

2. We developed another series of candidate architectures, for the regression
task of machine learning, based on assumed cascades of DNAzyme reactions.  These
theoretical outcomes helped drive the remaining, experimental outcomes:

3. We developed two families of cascades of DNAzyme reactions, including one
where we demonstrated five layers of signal propagation.

4. We combined DNAzyme and DNA strand displacement reactions into a modular
framework that allows us to build networks that query DNA targets down to the
picomolar range and to integrate the sensing of multiple targets into a logical
output.

5. We demonstrated DNA strand displacement reaction on cell surfaces,
integrating multiple surface markers into an output indicative of
healthy/diseased cell state.

Among the principal educational outcomes, 4 postdoctoral scholars, 12 graduate
students, 10 undergraduate students, and 3 high-school students were trained in
interdisciplinary research. A total of six PhD dissertations were completed with
support from the project.

In the project, we created and made publicly available two software frameworks:

1. The COEL chemistry simulation framework, the first web-based framework of its
kind: A visually pleasing and intuitive user interface, simulations that run on
a large computational grid, reliable database storage, and transactional
services make COEL ideal for collaborative research and education.  Source is
available at https://github.com/peterbanda/coel, and a live instance at
http://coel-sim.org.

2. The Stella domain-specific language for efficient scientific simulations
embedded in Python: The system makes it easier and quicker to write
well-performing scientific simulations that have single-thread performance
competitive with low-level languages, use object-oriented programming to
properly structure the code, and are very easy to develop. Source is available
at https://github.com/squisher/stella.
